awd_titl_txt: The Singularity Effect of Identifiable Victims
awd_abstract_narration:
The term "identified victim effect" refers to people's greater willingness to help identified victims (victims about whom they have some information) relative to unidentified persons. Past research suggests that the effect is restricted to single victims; meaning that identifying a single victim (by adding a name or a picture) increases helping, while the identification of individual members of a group has less effect on helping. This project explores the roots of the preference for helping a single, identifiable person, examining the development of this preference in young children within individualistic and collectivist societies. Hence the research intends to offer some insight into a most important facet of human social behavior: the willingness to help others in need. It aims to make significant theoretical contributions to understanding the sources of the identifiable victim effect and to the literature on the development of pro-social behavior.

The research team is conducting nine experiments. Some examine young children?s willingness to help identifiable single and group targets experiencing the same need to help clarify whether the identifiable victim effect develops with age and if so, when, in childhood, this tendency begins to appear. The research addresses the question of whether society can impart the feelings that are needed for enhancing caring for groups of people in need. In addition, the research explores whether the preference for helping the single identifiable victim may be a result of culture and education. Specifically, Western societies' individualism (according to which the individual person is the purpose for which society exists) may enhance people's caring for the one victim and cause the lack of relatedness to the group. If that is the case, it is expected that people in societies that hold more collectivistic views (emphasizing the primacy of the group or community rather than each individual person) will show no such preference. 

In addition to its theoretical contribution, the proposed research has important practical implications for increasing the frequency and strength of pro-social behavior as part of optimal human development.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit 

The term “identified victim effect” refers to people’s greater willingness to help people about whom they have some information relative to unidentified persons. Past research suggests that the effect is restricted to single victims; meaning that identifying a single victim (by adding a name or a picture) increases helping, while the identification of individual group members has less effect on helping. Moreover, a single identified victim evokes stronger feelings and greater willingness to help than an unidentified single victim or a group of victims, whether victims are identified or not. The preference for helping a single identified victim over a group of victims is known as the “singularity effect.” Previous research (Slovic, 2007) has shown that large numbers of victims fail to spark emotion and feelings and thus fail to motivate action. The current research explored cultural and developmental roots of the preference for helping a single, identifiable person.

Cultural sources: We examined individualistic and collectivist societies and found that western societies’ individualism (according to which the individual person is the purpose for which society exists) may enhance people’s caring for the one victim more than for a group. In our studies, people in more collectivist societies (emphasizing the primacy of the group or community rather than each individual person) and individuals with higher collectivist values showed no such preference and were willing to help single victims and groups to the same extent.

Developmental sources: Examining young children’s willingness to share with single targets and group targets we found that younger children tend to give more of their endowment to a group of recipients than to a single child. However, this tendency reversed for the older children (around the age of 6), who exhibited the singularity effect. Moreover, the development of the ability to see other’s needs in young children increases caring for individuals, but fails to encourage helping a group or crowd.

Our research contributes to the knowledge about one of the most important facets of human social behavior: the willingness to help others in need. It has theoretical contribution to the understanding of the sources of the identifiable victim and singularity effects and to the literature on the development of prosocial behavior. Both developmental and cultural approaches are relatively rare in the field of Judgment and Decision Making today, thus our research adds to the understanding of these important factors.

Broader Impacts

In addition to its theoretical contribution, our research has important broader impacts. It addresses the question of whether we can impart the feelings that are needed for enhancing caring for groups of people in need. A practical implication of the project is the possibility of increasing the frequency and strength of prosocial behavior as part of optimal human development, by considering the balance between individualism and collectivism in education and society. Our findings could also be applied in efforts to increase support for private and social causes in different cultures and societies and to enhance caring for groups in need.
